conclusion: Principles of shadow formation and effects of light source movement on shadow size and position are considered.
Shadows are formed when an object blocks light from a source, casting a silhouette on a surface.
The size and position of a shadow depend on the relative positions of the light source, the object, and the surface where the shadow is cast.
In the first image, shadows A, B, C, and D are cast by the objects on the ground.
The light source is positioned relatively close to the objects, resulting in shadows that are smaller and closer to the objects.
When the light source moves backward, the angle at which light hits the objects changes.
Moving the light source backward typically results in larger shadows because the light rays are more parallel, causing the shadow to stretch further on the ground.
The position of the shadows will shift, moving further away from the objects in the direction opposite to the light source.
In the second image, Shadow A has moved further away from the object (the sandal) and has increased in size.
Shadow B has shifted further from the object (the block) and has grown larger.
Shadow C has moved further from the object (the cake) and has become larger.
Shadow D has shifted further from the object (the sculpture) and has increased in size.
As the light source moves backward above the objects, shadows A, B, C, and D will move further away from their respective objects and increase in size.
